Resource Guide for FMSS Physical Security Protection Program (PSPP) Section Chief is respon- sible for planning, developing, implementing, evaluating, and controlling managers security handbook resource guide policy and guidance. IRS managers are responsible for: a. Taking all reasonable actions to prevent the loss of life and property, ruption of services and functions, and unauthorized disclosure of documents and information to safeguard the continued operation of the federal tax administration system. b. Enforcing compliance with minimum security standards and policies contained herein. c. Conﬁrming employees have knowledge and understanding of physical security program roles and requirements d. Consulting with FMSS Security Section Chief (SSC) for above-standard physical security countermeasures. e. Conﬁrming the level of protection provided to prevent unauthorized dis- closure of sensitive information is commensurate with the information’s level of sensitivity. f. Conﬁrming the level of protection afforded to the media containing the information is commensurate with the value of the media. g. Conﬁrming physical security measures required for protecting life, infor- mation, property and all government assets are: i. applied within their area of supervision and ii. those measures meet the established minimum-security standards. h. Maintaining effective controls to prevent fraud, waste, or abuse of gov- ernment resources and mismanagement of IRS programs. The control systems will provide reasonable assurance that all resources are safe- guarded from unauthorized use or disposition. The basic standards and principles of the control system for all managers are: i. Documentation - Clearly written instructions for all ﬁnancial transac- tions, accounting for resources and internal control requirements will be readily available. ii. Accountability - Transaction registers will be maintained and periodically for the purpose of determining if transactions were properly authorized. Exceptions must be investigated, and corrective action be taken. iii. Separation of Duties - Duties such as authorizing, recording, receiving, making payments and reviewing or auditing will be assigned separate individuals to minimize the possibility of fraud, waste, or going undetected. iv. Supervision - Qualiﬁed and continuous supervision will be provided ensure compliance with procedures. Periodic reviews will be conducted by responsible managers. v. Access to Resources - Direct physical access to resources and indirect access by preparation or processing of documents will be to authorized personnel. vi. Competent Assurance - Key personnel staff are of high integrity are competent by education, training, or experience to accomplish their duties.vii.Reasonable Assurance - Internal control systems will provide rea- sonable assurance that system objectives are met. The controls cost must not exceed the beneﬁts. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
Y

Controlled Area - Is not a Limited Area; however, it requires controlled entry access with one-part authentication (access card or manual combination).
Note: For additional information, see IRM 10.23.2, Personnel Security, Contractor Investigations.
) Facility Access - Controlled entry into a facility based on access status, role or function and employment category. (
) Incident - Any event affecting the safety, security, or protection of property, a facility, or occupant that requires a response, investigation, or other (
) Limited Area - An area to which access is limited to authorized personnel only. Limited Area space can be identiﬁed by the FMSS Physical SSC based on critical assets.
Incident - Any event affecting the safety, security, or protection of property, a facility, or occupant that requires a response, investigation, or other follow-up.
Note: For additional information, see IRM 10.2.14, Methods of Providing Protection.
1.4 Resource Guide for Managers

) Qualiﬁed Escort - An authorized (designated) IRS employee or a contractor employee approved for ﬁnal staff-like access at the same or higher position risk level as the contractor employee who requires escorting, and with knowledge of the task or activity to be performed.

Qualiﬁed Escort - An authorized (designated) IRS employee or a contractor employee approved for ﬁnal staff-like access at the same or higher position risk level as the contractor employee who requires escorting, and with knowledge of the task or activity to be performed.
times a week. (
) Security Section Chief (SSC) - An FMSS Operations manager responsible for physical security within a geographical area. (

) Staff-like Access - Authorized unescorted access to Treasury-owned or con- trolled facilities, IT systems, security items and products, and/or to areas storing/processing SBU data, as determined by Treasury/bureau officials. Staff- like access may be interim or ﬁnal.
Note: For additional information, see IRM 10.23.2, Personnel Security, Contractor Investigations.
Unescorted Access
Staff

like access granted to a contractor employee to IRS facilities, IT systems, and SBU data without escort. Extended deﬁnition: authority granted to individuals to gain access/entry and be present without an escort. Unescorted access is an element of staff
like access authorization.
Note: For additional information, see IRM 10.23.2, Personnel Security, Investigations.

) A guiding principle of security within IRS is “limiting access to assets based need”. When applied to information security, this translates into limiting to documents on a need-to-know basis. With regard to physical security, it means restricting entrance to rooms, areas, or facilities based on the al’s duties or responsibilities. (

) To maintain reasonable security at all IRS facilities at all times only visitors will be permitted to enter the facility. Providing tours for interested, tax related individuals, or groups for purposes of orienting them with facility operations is NOT authorized. (

) Official visits by individual tax preparers, tax accountants, news media sentatives and other professional tax-oriented individuals and groups may permitted at the discretion of the director of the facility or Senior Representative (SCR), in coordination with Communication and Liaison the local FMSS Physical Security staff.

) Determining the need to access information, documents, rooms, areas or ties is based on whether an individual needs access to perform assigned duties and responsibilities. Does the individual need to know? Does the indi- vidual need to enter a secured area? (

) Management determines of need and the subsequent decision to grant to an asset. Consult with the local FMSS Physical Security staff to select the appropriate means to achieve the desired access control. (

) The safeguards presented in this handbook are designed to protect against such human threats as: a. acts of violence b. accidental/deliberate alteration or destruction of information or property c. bomb threats d. demonstrations/riots e. fraud f. sabotage g. theft h. unauthorized disclosure i. unauthorized entry j. vandalism (

) The methods of protection are designed for comprehensive protection of assets at all times. The methods of protection are also designed to limit by non-IRS individuals who may require access to IRS facilities. (

) Because any single safeguard is often insufficient protection for any asset, concept of layering of safeguards was developed to provide in-depth To understand in-depth security, it is important to know what must be ered before choosing the appropriate safeguard, or combination of required for a particular asset. The value of the asset and any applicable are the primary considerations. Once these are determined, the problem of unauthorized access is approached by one or all of these methods: a. Deter b. Detect c. Deny d. Delay e. Defend/Respond (

) Ideally, physical security measures must provide a facility with absolute tion from a host of threats. Although absolute protection is unachievable, a practical approach to physical security is essential to protect personnel, mation, facilities, and property by employing a combination of measures to deter, detect, deny, delay, defend against unauthorized entrants without so restrictive that security itself becomes a disruption. The Minimum Protection Standards (MPS) system establishes a uniform method for protecting assets that require safeguarding. The MPS system is designed to provide managers with a basic framework of minimum physical security requirements with ﬂexibility to deal with local conditions.
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 10.2.15, Minimum Protection Standards (MPS), and IRM 10.2.11, Basic Physical Security Concepts.

) The designation of a Limited Area is a method of controlling the movement of individuals and eliminating unnecessary traffic through critical security areas, thereby reducing the risk for unauthorized disclosure or theft of tax information. Limited Area space can be identiﬁed by the FMSS Physical SSC based on critical assets. All Limited Areas must meet secured area requirements.

The designation of a Limited Area is a method of controlling the movement of individuals and eliminating unnecessary traffic through critical security areas, thereby reducing the risk for unauthorized disclosure or theft of tax information. Limited Area space can be identiﬁed by the FMSS Physical SSC based on critical assets. All Limited Areas must meet secured area requirements.
Note: For additional information on Limited Areas, see IRM 10.2.11, Basic Physical Security Concepts.
) Secured areas are designed to prevent undetected entry by unauthorized persons. (

) The local on-site FMSS Physical Security staff will retain keys to IRS space, in the event of inadvertent office lockouts. Spare keys may be retained by a des- ignated off-site business function for use in catastrophic situations where local personnel are available to provide access to IRS space. (
) No more than two keys are authorized for each locking mechanism FMSS budgets for and funds maintenance and replacement of office access controls, locks and keys. (

) Combinations to security containers storing classiﬁed NSI must be protected at the level of the information being stored in the containers. This includes ensuring that the combinations are never discussed outside of a secure area, that they are never written down and that the combinations are changed by a cleared, knowledgeable employee when individuals who had access no longer require it.
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 10.9.1, National Security Information.
required by the local Physical Security staff and control of SF

will remain in CI. Information protection is a vital matter to the IRS. All IRS employees having access to tax returns or return information and privacy information are prohib- ited by statute from disclosing official information except as authorized by applicable law or regulation. Information security includes information stored on handheld communication devices, external storage devices, computers, laptops or hard copy documents. In addition to tax data there are many other documents that require protection from disclosure.
Note: Protection of information discussed in this section is vital to the business of the IRS, however, it must not be confused with classiﬁed NSI.
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 10.5.1, Privacy and Information Protection, Privacy Policy.
The Privacy Act of
USC

a, provides comprehensive statutory ognition of an individual’s right to privacy. Recorded information which is retrieved by reference to a name or other personal identiﬁer, such as a security number, is privacy information. The act speciﬁes that agencies will establish appropriate administrative, technical, and physical safeguards to ensure the security of records and protect records against any anticipated threats or hazards to their security or integrity which could cause substantial harm, embarrassment, inconvenience, or unfairness to any individual about whom information is maintained.

tion Protection, Incident Management Program. Persons furnishing information on tax violations expect and deserve to have their identity protected. All employees must, therefore, handle such in strict conﬁdence. In order to maintain maximum security, informant commu

nications, claims for rewards, reward reports, memorandums or other documents which identify informants will be afforded contained protection at times, except when such documents are being processed. Access to such storage containers will be limited to the person/persons responsible for the
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 25.2, Information and Awards.

Classiﬁed NSI is any information, regardless of form, pertaining to the defense or foreign relations of the United States, that is owned by, produced by/for, or is under the control of the U.S. Government and, if not properly protected, could cause damage to National Security. Executive Order

, Classiﬁed National Security Information, or replacement, prescribes a uniform system for classifying, safeguarding, and declassifying national security infor- mation. NSI, commonly referred to as classiﬁed information, is information requires protection against unauthorized disclosure and should only be accessed by those with a clearance at or higher than the information to be accessed, a need-to-know to perform their duties, and a signed SF-

, siﬁed Information Nondisclosure Agreement. NSI is marked Top Secret, or Conﬁdential to indicate its need for protection regardless of the form it’s in. NSI must be transported in a particular manner and cannot be processed on unclassiﬁed systems, it must also be destroyed using the latest National Security Agency/Central Security Service (NSA/CSS) Evaluated Products List (EPL) shredder.
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 10.9.1, National Security Information.

) SBU data is any information which if lost, stolen, misused, or accessed or altered without proper authorization, may adversely affect the national interest or the conduct of federal programs (including IRS operations), or the privacy which individuals are entitled under the Privacy Act. (
) SBU data includes, but is not limited to: a. Tax information (Federal Tax Information (FTI) protected by IRC §

), Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII), Protected Health Information (PHI), certain procurement information, system vulnerabilities, case tion methodologies, system information, enforcement procedures, gation information. b. Live data, which is deﬁned as production data in use. Live means that when changing the data, it changes in production. The data may be ex- tracted for testing, development, etc., in which case, it is no longer Live data often contains SBU data (including PII and tax information); however, tax information (FTI) remains tax information (FTI) whether it is live in a production environment or is removed to a non-production environment. Note: For additional guidance, see IRM
, Sensitive But (SBU) Data Policy: Protecting SBU in Non-Production Environments. (

, Conceal- ment, Removal, or Mutilation Generally, it is unlawful to remove records or documents from the custody of the IRS except in accordance with prescribed procedures. The Tax Reform Act of
provides that returns and return mation are to be conﬁdential and not subject to disclosure, except as speciﬁcally provided in IRC
, Conﬁdentiality and Disclosure of Returns and Return Information, or other sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Note: For additional guidance, see IRM
, Records and Information Manage- ment, The Records and Information Management Program. (
) A large volume of the IRS assets such as tax returns, remittances and ment checks are transmitted by mail. Unattended mail is an easy target for theft. (
) Mail, not being distributed or processed, must be: a. stored in a secured area or in locked containers. b. not left unattended in areas open to the public. Note: For additional guidance, see IRM
, Privacy and Information Protection, Privacy Policy and IRM
, Mail and Transportation Management, Mail Operations.

SBU data is any information which if lost, stolen, misused, or accessed or altered without proper authorization, may adversely affect the national interest or the conduct of federal programs (including IRS operations), or the privacy to which individuals are entitled under the Privacy Act. ), Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII), Protected Health Information (PHI), certain procurement information, system vulnerabilities, case selec- tion methodologies, system information, enforcement procedures, investi- gation information. b. Live data, which is deﬁned as production data in use. Live means that when changing the data, it changes in production. The data may be ex- tracted for testing, development, etc., in which case, it is no longer ″live″. Live data often contains SBU data (including PII and tax information); however, tax information (FTI) remains tax information (FTI) whether it is live in a production environment or is removed to a non-production environment. Field employees may, at times, have sensitive and/or Personal Identiﬁable In- formation (PII) at the taxpayer’s site (location where taxpayer conducts business or houses tax information). Since it is not always possible to remove the information from the taxpayer’s site and store it at an IRS facility, managers must conﬁrm that employees understand the importance of securing such information at the taxpayer’s site in a locked container when not in use.
Field employees may, at times, have sensitive and/or Personal Identiﬁable In

formation (PII) at the taxpayer’s site (location where taxpayer conducts business or houses tax information). Since it is not always possible to remove the information from the taxpayer’s site and store it at an IRS facility, managers must conﬁrm that employees understand the importance of securing such information at the taxpayer’s site in a locked container when not in use.

Sensitive tax information, such as agent’s work papers, original returns, examination plans, fraud data, etc., which is housed at a taxpayer’s site must be stored in a security container under the control of the respon
sible employee. The taxpayer cannot have access to this container. Data will not be stored on the taxpayer’s premises during non

duty hours if a security container is not available. During duty hours, the data must be under the personal custody of the employee when it is not contained. Personal custody exists when a responsible IRS employee or other des

ignated person (e.g. armored car service employee, authorized employee of a contract ﬁrm) has possession of, or visual contact with, a document or item of property. For the purpose of this deﬁnition, visual contact is limited to the person’s desk or immediate work area over which he/she has physical control.

Sensitive tax information, such as agent’s work papers, original returns, examination plans, fraud data, etc., which is housed at a taxpayer’s site must be stored in a security container under the control of the respon- sible employee. The taxpayer cannot have access to this container. Data will not be stored on the taxpayer’s premises during non-duty if a security container is not available. During duty hours, the data must be under the personal custody of the employee when it is not contained. Personal custody exists when a responsible IRS employee or other des- ignated person (e.g. armored car service employee, authorized of a contract ﬁrm) has possession of, or visual contact with, a document or item of property. For the purpose of this deﬁnition, visual contact is limited to the person’s desk or immediate work area over which he/she has physical control.

) While on official travel it is often necessary for employees to carry tax data, laptops, taxpayer’s checks and money orders, etc. Employees are responsible for the loss, theft or disappearance of IRS property when attributable to negli- gence. Employees in custody of sensitive information or IRS property while outside of an IRS office must protect such items to the maximum extent possible.
(05-04-2020) Protection Outside of IRS Offices
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 10.5.1, Privacy and Information Protection, Privacy Policy.

) The IRS routinely ships tax returns and return information between IRS locations, as well as to other federal and state agencies. Data in transit is es- pecially vulnerable to loss, destruction and disclosure. Such loss could result in irreparable damage to the government or taxpayers, delay tax processing, and damage the public image of the IRS. (

) All shipments of tax returns and return information from any processing or computing center, area office, posts of duty, or other agencies and jurisdictions must be documented and monitored to safeguard accountability and receipt for
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 10.5.1, Privacy and Information Protection, Privacy Policy.
1.4 Resource Guide for Managers

) The purpose of destroying waste material generated in the processing of tax documents or other related documents is to prevent the information from being disclosed to unauthorized personnel. Disposition and destruction of tax infor- mation must be in accordance with IRM
, Records and Information Management, Types of Records and Their Life Cycles. (

) To improve the level of protection provided tax and privacy data, the IRS has adopted a clean desk policy. The IRS Clean Desk Policy and containerization objectives are designed to address the protection of SBU data (including PII and tax information) throughout the privacy lifecycle. The Clean Desk Policy requirements apply to data left out in work areas (including those in telework and offsite locations) and non-secured containers, on credenzas, desktops, fax/copy machines, conference rooms, and in/out baskets. (
) All SBU data (including PII and tax information) in non-secured areas must be containerized during non-duty hours. (

) For some pipeline activities and processing conducted at Submission Process- ing centers, campuses, and computing centers, the volume of the tax information processed and the disruption to these operations might prevent containerization and Clean Desk implementation. Note: For additional guidance, see IRM
, Privacy and Information Protection, Privacy Policy.
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 10.5.1, Privacy and Information Protection, Privacy Policy.

A security program is more effective when all managers and employees are aware of security requirements, including the reasons for each security ment they are expected to follow or enforce. Security awareness is promoted by the attitudes and actions of managers. If managers can explain security quirements in various situations and show how these requirements apply to their work area, employees will usually accept the need as an integral part of their responsibilities. Management will implement a security awareness program and include: a. ITM Physical Security Mandatory Brieﬁng. b. security as a regular topic at periodic managerial meetings. c. a security orientation of all new employees within the ﬁrst seven days following employment. All seasonal employees will be given a refresher orientation during their ﬁrst seven business days or if they been in non-work status for at least nine months. Local management determine who will provide the orientation. d. recurring security brieﬁng sessions conducted throughout the year by all processing/computing center supervisors. Security brieﬁng sessions will also be provided at the beginning of each ﬁling season. e. a brieﬁng to each employee of special security requirements pertaining their particular work area within
business days of hiring. Plans must be made to properly protect and account for all tax data and

) The federal tax administration system is crucial to the economy of the United States and must be protected at all times. To provide adequate protection, it is necessary to develop policy, plans and procedures that will reduce the effect of incidents and emergencies. Incidents and emergencies are any situation or condition at the global, national, or local level, that threatens or has the potential to threaten the safety and security of employees, information, systems, equipment, facilities and/or infrastructure.
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 10.2.9, Occupant Emergency Planning.

conditions that affect the operation of the IRS. Analyzing these trends or patterns detected will assist in effective countermeasures development to minimize the effect of future disruptions. Employees will contact one of the following offices to report an incident based on what was lost, stolen, or disclosed: a. Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure Incident Management Office. If the breach involves an inadvertent unauthorized disclosure of SBU data, including PII and tax information, that is not taxpayer corre- spondence (see OTC in IRM
) b), such as a verbal disclosure, or an electronic disclosure such as SBU data or PII or FTI in an IRM section, Training Materials, Powe
oints, IRWeb, live test data uploaded to a system, etc., or lost/stolen/destroyed hardcopy records or documents, or packages lost/stolen during UPS or Fe

x shipment, or lost/stolen remittances, report it to PGLD/IM using the PII Breach Report- ing Form. b. The Office of Taxpayer Correspondence. If the breach involves tax- payer correspondence generated in any of the following formats: notices, letters, transcripts, faxes, EEFaxes, and other electronic transmissions such as e-mail, report it to OTC using the Servicewide Notice Program (SNIP) Erroneous Taxpayer Correspondence Reporting Form. c. The Computer Security Incident Response Center (CSIRC). If the dent/breach involves the loss or theft of an IRS IT asset, e.g., an IRS is- sued computer, laptop, router, printer, cell phone, Blac

erry, etc., or removable media (CD/DVD, ﬂash drive, ﬂoppy, etc.) or a non-government furnished/personally owned mobile device that accesses, processes, transmits, or stores IRS information, in support of the Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) program, report it to CSIRC using the Computer Security Incident Reporting Form, or by calling CSIRC at
d. The Situational Awareness Management Center (SAMC). If the inci- dent involves lost or stolen Smart-ID cards or lost or stolen pocket com- missions (credentials), report it to SAMC (within
minutes) using SAMC Incident Reporting Link and selecting the button, “Report a New Physical Incident”.
1.4 Resource Guide for Managers
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 10.2.8, Incident Reporting.

) Occupant Emergency Plans (OEP) are an essential part of a security program. Properly developed plans can reduce the threat to personnel, property, and other assets while minimizing work disruption. GSA requires an OEP for all federally occupied space. If the IRS is the primary occupant agency (the agency with the largest population in the facility) the designated official will develop, maintain and test the occupant emergency plan. The designated official is the highest ranking official of the primary occupant agency. Emergency situations must be addressed so that personnel will know what procedures to follow. Typical situations and incidents included in the OEP are: bomb threats, explosions, demonstrations, Shelter in Place (SIP), utility disrup- tions or failures, natural disasters, disruptive weather, ﬁres, accidents, Code Adam/Amber, Active Threats, etc.
Note: For additional guidance see IRM 10.2.9, Occupant Emergency Planning.

) A Continuity Plan is a guide to reestablishing orderly operations after an incident. The plan’s objective is to resume processing of critical functions as quickly as possible and eventually resume full, normal operations. A properly developed Continuity plan requires coordination with all IRS organizations located at the facility. Each function will participate in the development of the plan by identifying critical needs (i.e. critical personnel and equipment needs, etc.) and will assign personnel to participate in the planning process. Emergency management planning must include recovery of critical systems human resources, vital records, telecommunications, security, mental concerns, and the facility which houses the work environment. Note: For additional guidance, see IRM
, Continuity Operations, Overview Continuity Planning, and IRM

, Records and Information Types of Records and Their Life Cycles when planning and developing nuity of operations for Vital Records, considered essential to the continued operation of the IRS before, during and after an emergency or disaster. (

A Continuity Plan is a guide to reestablishing orderly operations after an incident. The plan’s objective is to resume processing of critical functions as quickly as possible and eventually resume full, normal operations. A properly developed Continuity plan requires coordination with all IRS organizations located at the facility. Each function will participate in the development of the plan by identifying critical needs (i.e. critical personnel and equipment needs, etc.) and will assign personnel to participate in the planning process. Emergency management planning must include recovery of critical information systems human resources, vital records, telecommunications, security, mental concerns, and the facility which houses the work environment.

) Authorized photo ID cards are the Smar
D and Physical Access Card cards. (
) Smar
D cards may be issued to individuals who meet the eligibility require- ments for staff-like access and require routine access to IRS controlled facilities and/or information systems. (
) PAC cards may be issued to individuals who meet the eligibility for staff-like access and require routine access to IRS controlled facilities (
) The Smar
D will be worn above the employee’s waist (on the torso) with photo clearly visible from the front while in IRS facilities. Smar
D cards be carried in an IRS issued holder to safeguard the ID card certiﬁcate. All cards must be recovered from employees who separate from the IRS.
PAC cards may be issued to individuals who meet the eligibility requirements for staff-like access and require routine access to IRS controlled facilities only.
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 10.2.5, Identiﬁcation Media.
Visitors and federal or non-federal personnel who have met the eligibility quirements for staff-like access as set forth in IRM

, Physical Control (PAC) will be issued non-photo “Visitor” ID cards by the local Physical Security staff for unescorted access. Non-photo ID cards are issued by the local FMSS Physical Security staff a. Visitors, to include federal and non-federal personnel who met the ity requirements for staff-like access, as set forth in IRM

, Physical Access Control (PAC). b. Visitors, to include contractors and federal or non-federal personnel have not met the eligibility requirements for staff-like access. These cards will be clearly marked “ESCORT ONLY”. c. Employees reporting to IRS facilities without their photo ID card. Visitors who have not met the eligibility requirements must: a. be escorted by an IRS employee, who must request his/her on the facility visitor access list. b. present a valid photo ID card for identity veriﬁcation card and submit facility entry screening procedures. c. be issued a non-photo “Visitor Escort Only” ID card. Non-photo ID cards cannot be removed from the issuing facility and never be used as access authorization to a facility. Non-photo ID cards be returned to local FMSS Physical Security staff or guard post by the vidual assigned the card when the individual departs the facility or area. Limited Area Non-photo ID cards are issued by designated business unit limited area monitors. Pocket commissions are used to present proof of authority in the of official duties. They are primarily intended to identify IRS personnel to public when dealing with tax matters and may not be issued merely to employees for transaction of routine business. ) A PC issued in a registered pseudonym may not be used as a retirement memento, for an honorary presentation, or for similar purpose. A registered pseudonym PC holder may not be reissued a PC in their legal name for memento purposes. The PC must be recovered by the employee’s manager and sent to the PC team for destruction. ) Access to IRS facilities and work areas is provided to IRS employees, contrac- tors and visitors on an escorted or unescorted basis. The local FMSS physical security office will determine and grant the type of access, based on the eligi- bility requirements. (

) All persons entering or requesting access to a government building are subject to the provisions of the rules and regulations governing public buildings and grounds. This includes Federal Management Regulation (FMR), Title
, Code of Federal Regulations (CFR); Part
, Subpart C Conduct on Federal Property and Title
, United States Code (USC), Section
, Possession of Firearms and Dangerous Weapons in Federal Facilities.

) Non-federal personnel who meet eligibility requirements can be issued a Physical Access Card (PAC) for use at that facility, after a favorable tion for staff-like access. Any issued Non-photo ID cards must not be from the issuing facility. (
) Contractors, meeting the unescorted access requirements that do not have IRS issued photo ID card may be placed on a VAR, approved by the local FMSS physical security office.

) IRS contractors, other federal agency employees and contractors and that do not meet the requirements for unescorted access must be escorted all times while in IRS facilities and workspace. Escorted access does not for the entry and/or movement throughout the facility without a qualiﬁed (

) Escorted persons require a qualiﬁed escort. The requirements for qualiﬁed escort are authorized (designated) IRS or contractor employees approved ﬁnal staff-like access at the same or higher position risk level as the person. (

) Employees and authorized contractors requiring routine access to IRS con- trolled facilities with an electronic access control system may be issued a facility access card, also known as the proxy card, where required. (

) Employees that require a proxy card must complete and submit Form Request for ID Media and/or Access Card for IRS Employees, to the local FMSS Physical Security staff in order to obtain their proxy card. (

) The IRS has established minimum security standards and requirements managers must safeguard. Recurring assessments and reviews assist personnel and management officials in determining the effectiveness and propriateness of existing safeguards and security guidelines. (

) Functional reviews measure compliance with security policy and that apply to each manager’s office or functional area. Functional reviews managers to verify that existing security policy and procedures are being followed daily. (
) Front line managers must conduct functional reviews on at least an annual basis or more frequently depending on their business unit’s security ments. The review must be documented on Form

and the reviewer must provide copy of the report to the next level of management. Review criteria may be based on local concerns, but managers should evaluate area on: a. Clean Desk Policy b. Disposition of waste material c. ID Media d. Locks and keys e. Protection of sensitive information f. Security awareness
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM 10.2.18, Physical Access Control (PAC).

1.4 Resource Guide for

) An after-hours review allows managers to determine if assets are protected when not in the custody of authorized IRS personnel. Managers Review accomplish this by checking the area after the close of the business day or before the facility opens to review the workspace for compliance. (

) Managers: a. periodically review functional areas after hours to determine if information is appropriately contained, disposed of, whether cabinets, safes and other containers are appropriately secured and whether areas, secure areas and office doors meet security requirements. b. take immediate action for identiﬁed weaknesses to safeguard property or rooms/facility, counsel employees as appropriate, and/or request assistance from the local FMSS SSC to develop corrective measures. (

) Contracts for services or property involving the disclosure of sensitive tion to a contractor (e.g. return or return information, personnel information Site Surveys administrative or internal management information critical to mission of the IRS), must include appropriate protective measures in accordance with cable laws, regulations and procedures. IT Cybersecurity and FMSS, can assist in the review and provide their respective expertise. Note: Refer to Servicewide Records Management Guidance Regarding Records. (
) Managers conﬁrm requests for contracted services involving disclosure of sensitive information are reviewed by PGLD and where appropriate, IT security, as well as FMSS Physical Security. (
) Managers consult with FMSS Physical Security staff to determine contractor site survey and security requirements. (
) For automated information services, see IRM
, Information (IT) Security, Policy and Guidance. (

) An existing contractor’s ability to adequately protect IRS data from ized use or disclosure must be recertiﬁed annually for contracts which beyond a one-year period, prior to contract renewal or if the safeguards employed by the contractor become a matter of concern (e.g. suspected security breach). (
) Contact the Privacy, Governmental Liaison, and Disclosure Incident ment Office if the recertiﬁcation is conducted due to a disclosure concern to brief them about the concern. (

) The contractor will be requested to provide a self-assessment regarding ability to protect IRS data. If recertiﬁcation status cannot be determined the self-assessment and other documentation, a contractor facility tion site review must be scheduled. Due to regulatory requirements, IRS security (Cybersecurity and/or FMSS) may perform site reviews annually depending on the nature of the issue (i.e., Federal Information Security agement Act (FISMA), see Pub.
, Contractor Security Controls).
